awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Resolving drivers of variation in grassland community assembly and restoration
awd_abstract_narration:
The destruction and modification of natural ecosystems for human land uses, like agriculture, together pose the greatest threat to the world's biodiversity. In turn, ecological restoration has been hailed as a critical conservation tool for its ability to promote biodiversity through the repair of damaged ecosystems and creation of new habitats. Yet, restoration outcomes are notoriously unpredictable and this hinders land managers' abilities to reliably repair damaged ecosystems. This project will evaluate the causes of variation in restoration outcomes by investigating the process of community assembly - how assemblages of species develop over time - during restoration. In doing so, it will guide restoration practice, advance the field of restoration ecology through the coupling of basic ecological theory and ecosystem management, and test long-standing, fundamental questions about why the diversity and composition of ecological communities vary among locations. Furthermore, this project will train new restoration scientists and strengthen linkages between restoration research and practice through classroom instruction, student and postdoc training, and partnerships with land management agencies conducting restoration.

This project will take place within a system of prairie grasslands restored through the sowing of native prairie seeds onto former agricultural lands. A goal of this work will be to understand how community assembly and restoration outcomes are influenced by environmental conditions that vary in space and time (soil fertility and rainfall), and as a function of two factors describing ecological communities - the number of species and number of individuals for each species, within communities. Focal questions will be evaluated experimentally and across a network of large-scale grasslands undergoing restoration, forging a link between mechanism-oriented experiments and real-world assembled ecosystems.

por.por_cntn:
The destruction and degradation of natural ecosystems for human land uses, like agriculture, is the greatest threat to the world's biodiversity. In turn, ecological restoration has been hailed as a critical conservation tool for its ability to promote biodiversity through the repair of damaged ecosystems and creation of new habitats. Yet, restoration outcomes are notoriously variable, ranging from dramatic success to striking failure, and we typically do not understand reasons for this variability. This in turn hinders land managers' abilities to reliably repair damaged ecosystems.


This project evaluated the causes of variation in restoration outcomes by investigating the process of community assembly - how assemblages of species develop over time - during restoration. In doing so, it provided guidance to restoration practice, advancing the field of restoration ecology through the coupling of basic ecological theory and ecosystem management, and tested long-standing, fundamental questions about why the diversity and composition of ecological communities varies among locations. 

We evaluated these questions with prairie grasslands, which are undergoing restoration from abandoned farmlands. In these grasslands, native prairie seeds are planted to assist these species’ arrival and initiate the restoration process. We conducted experiments where we conducted prairie restorations ourselves in Michigan, testing reasons for variable outcomes, and also worked across a network of ongoing prairie restorations in Illinois, Indiana, and Michigan.

There were three major Intellectual Merit outcomes of this grant. 1) We showed how variation in plant assemblages during restoration is a result of how plant species respond to their local environment. Our research identified two especially important aspects of the local environment: attributes of the soil and the amount of rainfall during the year after a prairie was planted. Surprisingly, prairies planted during years with less abundant rainfall tended to foster more native prairie species and fewer plant species not typical of prairies, including exotic species. These species responses, in turn, are influenced by specific attributes of plant species, such as their height or size of their seeds. 2) Effects of the local environment are modified by the number of prairie species and density of seeds planted to initiate a restoration project. Prairies planted with seeds of more species became more diverse, supporting more species of plants. Prairies planted with a greater density of seeds were less variable in their outcomes. 3) The plant assemblage within a prairie influences other aspects of prairie ecosystems, such as rates of primary productivity and the production of floral resources for pollinators.

This project supported four main types of Broader Impacts. 1) Redesign of the Restoration Ecology course at Michigan State University around hands-on restoration research and practice. A centerpiece of this effort was the development of an 'outdoor classroom' on Michigan State University’s campus, through which hundreds of Michigan State University undergraduate students engaged in the study of restoration ecology. 2) Training of undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and technicians in restoration research and practice. This project helped to support research led by seven PhD students, three postdocs, nine undergraduates, and one post-bac student. These individuals collectively led the publication of 12 research articles and the majority participated in hands-on restoration work, such as invasive species removal, native species planting, and prescribed fire management. 3) We made a substantial amount of data publicly available, including data on plant species composition and environmental attributes from >80 prairie restorations in our region, and eight other datasets.4) Research to inform restoration of imperiled tallgrass prairies from former farmland. Tallgrass prairies are highly imperiled due largely to farmland conversion. There is substantial interest in restoring former farmlands to prairie by sowing seeds of native prairie plants onto abandoned agricultural fields. Our project assists these efforts by understanding the determinants of variation among outcomes and informing the design of seed mixes - decisions about which species and how many seeds to add during restoration.
